block.p: 171 Killed in Deadliest Day Of Baghdad Security Plan Bombs ravaged Baghdad in five explosions aimed mainly at Shiite crowds, killing at least 171 people in the deadliest day in the capital since the American-led security plan for the city took effect.

After weeks of sparring over financing the next phase of the war in Iraq, President Bush and Congressional leaders softened their tone but failed to resolve their differences over a timeline for the withdrawal of American troops.

Anger in Iran After Court Ruling The Iranian Supreme Court has overturned the murder convictions of six members of a prestigious state militia who killed five people they considered ''morally corrupt.'' The reversal has produced anger and controversy across Iran.

Aid for Endangered Crops Repositories of endangered crops that underpin the global food supply are eroding with regularity, experts say, as war, storms or bad management cause seed stores to deteriorate. Now, the first international effort to restore the repositories will receive an infusion of funds.
Bush Presses Sudan on Darfur President Bush warned Sudan that the United States would impose stiff economic sanctions if it did not bring an end to the violence in Darfur.
3 Evangelicals Slain in Turkey Three people were found with their throats slit in a publishing house in eastern Turkey that printed Bibles and other Christian literature, the authorities said.

Justices Uphold a Ban On Late-Term Abortion The Supreme Court reversed course on abortion, upholding the federal Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act in a 5-to-4 decision that promises to reframe the abortion debate and define the young Roberts court.

Gunman Sent Videotape to NBC Campus authorities were aware of the troubled mental state of the student who shot and killed 32 people and himself at Virginia Tech, an imbalance displayed in a package of vengeful videos, writing and photographs mailed to NBC News.
Across the nation, Koreans have braced for harassment in the wake of a shooting rampage on the Virginia Tech campus committed by Cho Seung-Hui, who was born in South Korea.

Senate Blocks Medicare Plan A pillar of the Democrats' program tumbled when the Senate blocked a proposal to let Medicare negotiate lower drug prices for millions of older Americans, a practice now forbidden by law.
Red Cross Names New Chief The American Red Cross named Mark W. Everson, the commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, as its president and chief executive. He is expected to take over in May.

Colleges Review Loan Practices Colleges and universities are scrambling to review the practices of their financial aid offices as a result of an expanding investigation into the ties between university officials and lenders.

High Speeds Not Unusual For New Jersey Governors Former governors of New Jersey say it was not unusual for their drivers to exceed the speed limit when the governor was running late for a meeting, which was the case when Gov. Jon S. Corzine's sport utility vehicle crashed on a highway, critically injuring him.

4 Dead in Murder-Suicide A 20-year-old man with a history of mental disturbance shot and killed his mother, her companion and her companion's health care aide before killing himself in Queens, the police said.
Floods Continue After Storm The northeaster of 2007 is over, but thousands of residents in towns along the Passaic River in New Jersey are being forced from their homes by surging floodwaters.

Living Without BlackBerrys More than five million American BlackBerry users faced 10 hours without wireless e-mail. That grueling experience revealed just how dependent many have become on these electronic lifelines.
Kitty Carlisle Hart A perennial entertainer who appeared on Broadway and in films and was still singing on the stage as recently as last fall, she was 96.
Editorials: Denying the right to choose; no more delay on Darfur; the silence of politicians; a government of laws and seat belts.
